newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL overnight rises on squaring ahead of weekend.
newsitem.headline: KL overnight rises on squaring ahead of weekend.

text.p: KUALA LUMPUR, July 25 (Reute) - The overnight interbank rate rose to 8.7/8 percent against 8.4/5 previously as banks rushed to square up their positions ahead of the weekend in a liquidity-short market, dealers said on Friday.
They said some Bank Negara agents continued lending, but the market was too short to prevent a spike up in rates.
"They were not really injecting money this afternoon. They were just helping people square up," said a dealer with a Malaysian bank in Kuala Lumpur.
Interbank rates rose despite fresh injection of funds into the banking system by Bank Negara Malaysia, dealers said.
They said rates started rising soon after the central bank's agents stopped making offers in mid-morning trading.
"The funds were obviously not enough. Once the agents stopped, merchant banks and other small guys started bidding rates up," said the head of money dealing at a local bank.
There was no confirmation of the funds injection from Bank Negara, which does not usually comment on its market operations.
He said rates would have gone up further but for a persistent rumour about a possible cut in banks' statutory reserves requirement (SRR).
Banks in Malaysia have to maintain a certain percentage of their deposits in liquid assets, mainly government paper.

Dealers said one-week money was at 8.6/7 percent against 8.00/30 on Thursday, one-month at 8.4/5 percent against 8.0, three-month at 8.3/5 percent against 7.8/8.0 and six-month at 8.0/8.3 percent against 7.8/8.0.
Bank Negara is said to have injected funds over the past 10 days to help ease market tightness.
Recent heavy buying of the ringgit by the central bank to defend the currency from speculative attack had caused a liquidity squeeze.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange were down across the board to reflect the rebound in interest rates, futures dealers said.
At noon, the three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) September contract was down eight points to 92.32, or an implied yield of 7.68 percent.
The December contract was down eight at 92.54, or 7.46 percent.
